Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Gaining Visibility into Supply Network Risks with Large-Scale Textual Analysis

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Globalization and the quest for lean production have significantly increased vulnerability of contemporary supply chains. A disruptive event in Bangkok can stop production in Beijing, and in turn hamper product delivery in Boston. Such events materialize in various, sometimes unexpected forms: natural disasters, labor protests, utility outage, cyber-attacks, political shifts, and epidemic outbreaks, to name a few. They can lead to cascading supply chain failures and business continuity interruptions, with potentially severe near- and long-term physical, financial, and reputational consequences. The key barrier to the effective management of supply chain disruptions is the limited visibility into the interconnected supply network structure and the associated risk profiles. For example, the Department of Defense has specifically highlighted limited visibility of supply chain structures and risks as items of high strategic risks in 2015. This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project directly addresses this challenge. It develops predictive analytics, risk learning and mitigation strategies that can be readily deployed by firms and organizations to increase visibility and control of their supply chain risks. The data driven approach is particularly useful to organizations with complex supply chains, such as multinational firms and governmental agencies, to better measure the distribution and impact of supply network risks, and proactively manage such risks and achieve better supply chain resilience.

While existing theories assume perfect knowledge of supply network structure and the associated risk profiles, this research follows a two-pronged approach to directly account for and mitigate limited visibility. First, it develops a series of empirical models that increase visibility into supply chain risks and their driving factors, with a particular emphasis on network-driven risk interdependencies. It is the first research to combine automated textual analysis (topic coding and sentiment analysis) and high-dimensional statistical analysis, to isolate supply risk information from large scale, qualitative data. Specifically, the project will quantify the language of corporate disclosures and user generated content on social media to 1) characterize risk distributions and interdependencies, 2) quantify the impacts of these risks on both immediate and sub-tier supply chain partners, and 3) identify early-warning factors and develop predictive models for risk events. Second, leveraging insights gained from the empirical results, this project develops new quantitative models on risk learning and mitigation that address and account for limited visibility. One class of models focuses on optimal risk learning given complete knowledge of supply network but incomplete knowledge of risks. The other class of models focuses on designing optimal risk mitigation strategies with general incomplete information. The model addresses effectiveness of direct (procuring excess inventory and multi-sourcing) versus indirect (supply contracts) mitigation strategies in a game-theoretic framework.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The lack of visibility into the extended supply chains?particularly the higher-tier connections beyond the direct supplier--customer linkages?is widely regarded as a significant risk source that is challenging to analyze and manage due to the lack of good data on (1) the supply chain network structure and (2) risk events originating from higher-tier suppliers, as well as the lack of (3) robust models that quantify on how risks propagate in the network. This award supports research that addresses all three aspects of the challenge.

First, we develop a series of models that relate supply chain disruptions and their financial impact on the focal firm to the degree of deeper-tier supplier overlap. Based on graph theory, we develop several measures such as supplier degree of commonality and supply network diamond ratio to quantify the average effect of sub-tier dependencies on firm risk. We empirically validate the models using new data on supply chain linkages. We construct a comprehensive, firm-level mapping of supply chain network in the manufacturing, high-tech, healthcare, and consumer goods industry groups using raw data on firm-to-firm business relationships database between 2011 and the end of 2018. Using the newly constructed dataset, we demonstrate the prevalence of sub-tier overlapping in all industry groups and quantify their financial impacts. We find that sub-tier dependencies are particularly prominent in the high-tech and manufacturing industries, largely due to lean inventory practices.

Second, using automated natural language processing techniques such as supervised latent Dirichlet allocation, we extract a large collection of exogenously idiosyncratic risk events originating from tier-2 suppliers, based on the analysis of their corporate filings and related news reports. Using this new data, we document that firms located outside the events' impact areas but whose tier-2 suppliers are located within the impact areas experience significantly negative abnormal returns after the events, with a higher magnitude as the degree of tier-2 overlaps increases.

Finally, we extend the scope of our risk analysis to the propagation of intangible and reputational risks in the supply chain network, using text-driven, event-based incidents data on firms' environmental, social and governance (ESG) risks. We find that, similar to physical risks such as disruptions, reputational risks--and their mitigation thereof--could propagate along both immediate and higher-order supply chains and translate into financial risks. Ongoing research develops additional measures of intangible risk propagation and quantifies its financial impact. 

Outcomes from this reward offer guidance on how to prioritize efforts devoted to increase supply chain visibility. In particular, firms and organizations should identify critical sub-tier suppliers shared by multiple immediate suppliers, increase monitoring frequency of these firms, and communicate with direct-tier suppliers to coordinate more effective risk-mitigation actions. In addition, to the extent that supply chain professionals lack clarity on the value of these risks and benefits from mitigation, we provide a systematic quantification of these values using concrete and accessible financial measures as well as event-based ESG indices. We disseminate the project outcomes through invited presentations to supply chain risk management practitioners and through undergraduate and graduate course development.
